frameDefinitions: A member or members of a Class have just been  mentioned or are present in the discourse setting and now a different instance  (or group of instances) of the same class is referred to.
The Authorities put a Prisoner in Prison as punishment for an Offense.
An Experiencer has an emotion as caused by a Stimulus or concerning a Topic.
A Cognizer makes a judgment about an Evaluee.
The words in this frame describe an Experiencer's emotions with respect to some Content.
A Communicator communicates a judgment of an Evaluee to an Addressee.
frameExamples: My husband left me for <t>another</t> woman -- and now wants to get back together again!
US Drug Researcher <t>Imprisoned</t> for FDA Fraud.
I fall asleep hours later to the sound of their <t>engrossed</t> murmuring.
JUDGMENT:  She <t>admired</t> Einstein for his character.
My <t>enjoyment</t> of the movie was considerably impaired by the seven-foot guy sitting in front of me.
I <t>commended</t> his handling of the crisis.
listRoleDefinitions: The general category of entity which has been referred to.
The instance of the <fen>Class</fen> that is added to the <fen>Initial_set</fen> of entities in the <fen>Class</fen>.
The previously mentioned group of entities of the <fen>Class</fen>.
The person who is confined in a penal institution.
The <fen>Prison</fen>  within which the <fen>Prisoner</fen> comes to be confined.
The <fen>Authorities</fen> are the institution or actors carrying out the imprisonment.
The time when the imprisonment happens.
This role identifies the <fen>Place</fen> where the <fen>Prisoner</fen> is kept.
The <fen>Experiencer</fen> is the person or sentient entity that experiences or feels the emotions.
The <fen>Topic</fen> is the general area in which the emotion occurs.  It indicates a range of possible <fen>Stimulus</fen>.
The <fen>Stimulus</fen> is the person, event, or state of affairs that evokes the emotional response in the <fen>Experiencer</fen>.
The <fen>State</fen> is the abstract noun that describes a more lasting experience by the <fen>Experiencer</fen>.

The body part, gesture, or other expression of the <fen>Experiencer</fen> that reflects his or her emotional state.  They describe a presentation of the experience or emotion denoted by the adjective or noun.
The Time when the <fen>Experiencer</fen> is has a feeling about the <fen>Stimulus</fen>.
The <fen>Cognizer</fen> makes the judgment. This role is typically expressed as the External Argument (or in a <ment>by</ment>-PP in passives).
Evaluee is the person or thing about whom/which a judgment is made. With verbs this role is typically expressed as Object:
Typically, there is a constituent expressing the <t>Reason</t> for the Judge's judgment. It is usually a <ment>for</ment>-PP, e.g.
<fen>Expressor</fen> is the body part or action by a body part that conveys the judgment made by the <fen>Cognizer</fen>.
The <fen>Experiencer</fen> experiences the emotion or other internal state.

<fen>Content</fen> is what the <fen>Experiencer</fen>'s feelings or experiences are directed towards or based upon.  The <fen>Content</fen> differs from a stimulus because the <fen>Content</fen> is not construed as being direcly responsible for causing the emotion.

The Frame Element <fen>Expressor</fen> marks expressions that indicate a body part, gesture or other expression of the <fen>Experiencer</fen> that reflect his or her emotional state.  They describe a presentation of the experience or emotion denoted by the adjective or noun.
The <fen>Topic</fen> is the area about which the <fen>Experiencer</fen> has the particular experience.
The <fen>State</fen> is the abstract noun that describes a more lasting experience by the <fen>Experiencer</fen>.
The <fen>Event</fen> is the occasion or happening that <fen>Experiencer</fen>s in a certain emotional state participate in.
The time at which the <fen>Experiencer</fen> is in the specified emotional state.
The <fen>Communicator</fen> uses language in the written or spoken modality to convey his or her evaluation of the <fen>Evaluee</fen> to another person.
<fen>Medium</fen> identifies the physical or abstract setting in which the evaluation is conveyed.
<fen>Topic</fen> identifies the entity to which the proposition or propositions conveyed relate.
A judgment is made about the <fen>Evaluee</fen>  With verbs this role is typically expressed as Object:
<fen>Expressor</fen> is the body part or action by a body part that conveys the judgment made by the <fen>Communicator</fen>.
Typically, there is a constituent expressing the <t>Reason</t> for the <fen>Communicator</fen>'s judgment. It is usually a <ment>for</ment>-PP.
When the communication of the judgment takes place.
Where the communication of the judgment takes place.
listRoleExamples: My Husband left me for another <fex>man</fex>!
There was <fex><t>another</t> power outage</fex> today.
A further five incursions <fex>over and above those noted for 1995</fex> took place in the first three months of 1996.
<fex>Man</fex> Falsely Imprisoned for 24 Years Seeks Damages
When she returned, <fex>the Chaoyang Town government authorities</fex> imprisoned her for 5 days.
<fex>The boss</fex> appreciates you for your diligence.
The boss appreciates <fex>you</fex> for your diligence.
I admire you <fex>for your intellect</fex>.
She viewed him with an appreciative <fex>gaze</fex>.
Everyone loves <fex>compliments</fex>.
The delight <fex>on her face</fex> was mixed with asonishment.
Mr. Whiskers was upset <fex>about his cat treats</fex>.
Tracy was in an irritated <fex>mood</fex>.
It felt pretty awkward to partake in such a nervous <fex>ceremony</fex>.
<fex>Last year</fex>, Bob was still interested in the young Republicans.
<fex>Jon</fex> belittled Madie to her colleagues.
Jon belittled Madie <fex>over the telephone</fex>.
Jon criticized Madie <fex>about her managerial style</fex>.
Jon belittled <fex>Madie</fex> to her colleagues.
She viewed him with a critical <fex>gaze</fex>.
Jon extolled Madie <fex>for her efforts</fex>.
He received critical acclaim <fex>last week</fex>.
He was belittled by his long-time friend <fex>in front of his family</fex>.
